newsitem.title: GERMANY: German employers seek compromise on sick pay cuts.
newsitem.headline: German employers seek compromise on sick pay cuts.

text.p: The umbrella organisation of Germany employers associations, the BDA, said on Wednesday it still supported the implementation of sick pay cuts where possible, but saw room for compromise on how they are imposed.
A group of large companies, led by Daimler-Benz AG, moved to enforce 20 percent sick pay cuts made possible by rule changes which took effect on October 1.
But they suspended their decisions pending a compromise with unions who called out auto workers in brief protests at what they called a violation of their work contracts.

"The ruling must, where possible, be carried out," BDA chief executive Reinhard Goehner told journalists in Bonn. But, he added there were many ways to do so, depending on how the wage basis for calculating sick pay is determined.

Talks are due to resume between the Gesamtmetall industrial employers group and the powerful IG Metall union on Thursday on sick pay. IG Metall has also announced its call for a 1997 pay increase of between 4.5 and five percent for its members.
